Posts.Content: Michael F - Good suggestion. I had a 3T MRI and a Choline PET scan at the Mayo Clinic 14 months ago. Neither test found any sign of cancer. I'm not sure whether that is a good thing or a bad thing. The question now is whether to go back to the Mayo Clinic (or somewhere) and repeat those tests. Maybe they will find something to "shoot at" during the radiation treatments.

Posts.Title: Update after 14 months

Posts.Content: Hi. I havent been on here in about 14 months. I have some previous posts explaining how I got here, and my results at the Mayo Clinic. This post is just kind of a recap of my PSA history and where I am right now in my journey. Please see my signature below. My urologist had been doing my PSA tests in the lab in his office until the end of 2016. In Jan 2017, he started sending them out to another lab. In Jan 2017, he told me that my PSA was .2, and he gave me the exact same number in Jul 2017. Since he had always given me a 2-digit number, I assumed he meant .20, but I was wrong. The new test he was using only went out one place. So I didnt know whether it was .20, .25, or .29. It makes a big difference. I was furious. I immediately stopped seeing that doctor, and made an appointment at the Mayo Clinic. They do a different type of PSA test and in Jul 2017 they said my PSA was .17. I know you have to have the exact same test from the same lab three times in a row to determine a real pattern, but the good news was that my PSA was probably closer to .20 than .29. I started having my family doctor do my PSA tests  same test and same lab  every three months. It was the ultra-sensitive PSA test. In Oct 2017, my PSA was .215. OK, it was a little higher than I had hoped, but it was just the first ultra-sensitive test using this lab. In Jan 2018, it was .213. Interesting. I knew my PSA was not going down, but maybe it was just going to stay level. That would be great. In Apr 2018, it was .230. Crap. And in Jul 2018, it was .261. Time to get serious. I know that .2 is/was considered the magic number to determine if the prostate cancer has returned. Some folks use .03. But my PSA progression had been so slow, and its been almost 12 years since my surgery. I was hoping that maybe, just maybe, it would continue to be very slow. I was in no hurry to have salvage radiation therapy. During the last year, I have met with four radiation oncologists, three local in Oklahoma City and one at the Mayo Clinic. Im finalizing plans to start SRT.

Posts.Content: Archer - I've seen the number 25% thrown around about needing salvage radiation. It really depends on a lot of things. One of the things is what your Gleason score is. Here are the numbers for different Gleasons: 3+3 = 5% 3+4 = 17% 4+3 = 35% 4+4 = 37% 9 or 10 = 76% The experience of the surgeon makes a huge difference too.

Posts.Title: Update after 14 months

Posts.Content: Another - I was 58 when I had my surgery, and I'm 70 now. My dad lived to be 95, following the removal of his prostate. He remained in the Zero club until his death. Other than prostate cancer, I'm very healthy. Gosh, it would be great if I lived be 95 like my dad. Your question about kicking the can could be interpreted a couple of ways. What did you mean?

I'm not sure whether that is a good thing or a bad thing. The question now is whether to go back to the Mayo Clinic (or somewhere) and repeat those tests. Maybe they will find something to "shoot at" during the radiation treatments.

Posts.Title: Update after 14 months

Posts.Content: Another - I was 58 when I had my surgery, and I'm 70 now. My dad lived to be 95, following the removal of his prostate. He remained in the Zero club until his death. Other than prostate cancer, I'm very healthy. Gosh, it would be great if I lived be 95 like my dad. Your question about kicking the can could be interpreted a couple of ways. What did you mean?

Posts.Title: Update after 14 months

Posts.Content: Hi. I havent been on here in about 14 months. I have some previous posts explaining how I got here, and my results at the Mayo Clinic. This post is just kind of a recap of my PSA history and where I am right now in my journey. Please see my signature below. My urologist had been doing my PSA tests in the lab in his office until the end of 2016. In Jan 2017, he started sending them out to another lab. In Jan 2017, he told me that my PSA was .2, and he gave me the exact same number in Jul 2017. Since he had always given me a 2-digit number, I assumed he meant .20, but I was wrong. The new test he was using only went out one place. So I didnt know whether it was .20, .25, or .29. It makes a big difference. I was furious. I immediately stopped seeing that doctor, and made an appointment at the Mayo Clinic. They do a different type of PSA test and in Jul 2017 they said my PSA was .17. I know you have to have the exact same test from the same lab three times in a row to determine a real pattern, but the good news was that my PSA was probably closer to .20 than .29. I started having my family doctor do my PSA tests  same test and same lab  every three months. It was the ultra-sensitive PSA test. In Oct 2017, my PSA was .215. OK, it was a little higher than I had hoped, but it was just the first ultra-sensitive test using this lab. In Jan 2018, it was .213. Interesting. I knew my PSA was not going down, but maybe it was just going to stay level. That would be great. In Apr 2018, it was .230. Crap. And in Jul 2018, it was .261. Time to get serious. I know that .2 is/was considered the magic number to determine if the prostate cancer has returned. Some folks use .03. But my PSA progression had been so slow, and its been almost 12 years since my surgery. I was hoping that maybe, just maybe, it would continue to be very slow. I was in no hurry to have salvage radiation therapy. During the last year, I have met with four radiation oncologists, three local in Oklahoma City and one at the Mayo Clinic. Im finalizing plans to start SRT.

Posts.Title: Update after 14 months

Posts.Content: Archer - I've seen the number 25% thrown around about needing salvage radiation. It really depends on a lot of things. One of the things is what your Gleason score is. Here are the numbers for different Gleasons: 3+3 = 5% 3+4 = 17% 4+3 = 35% 4+4 = 37% 9 or 10 = 76% The experience of the surgeon makes a huge difference too.

Posts.Title: Update after 14 months

Posts.Content: stephenb  I understand exactly where you are. See my stats below. As Michael F said, its really important for us to know your surgical pathology report in order to give you any insight as to what we believe (keep in mind that we are not doctors) a prudent course of action might be. For instance. If you had a Gleason 6, and if a Gleason 6 never metastasizes, whats the downside of delaying treatment? Would a positive margin change this? But if you had a Gleason 8, delaying treatment could be deadly  and quickly. Im also asking myself the same question. What if I simply wait and see what happens? Whats the downside? If I wait, whats the trigger that makes me say OK, now its time to take action? Unlike some others, it doesnt sound to me like youre giving up. It sounds like you want to make a critically important decision about how to spend the rest of your life. Seeking input from others who have been in a similar situation seems like a smart thing to do. Please provide us with your surgical pathology report. Im curious to see how close it is to mine. PCH

Posts.Content: Southsider - Thank you for the input. I have another thread about my specific situation (see It's Back). I was just hoping to generate some general discussion about post surgery rise in PSA. I realize that for a lot of people, it's simple. They had RP. Their first post surgery PSA is 1+ and it's doubling quickly. No doubt, it's time to take action. Then there are other folks who had little or no rise in PSA for a long time. And now it's going up very slowly. Sometimes it IS sort of tricky to decide when (or if) to start salvage radiation. What would the trigger be?

Posts.Title: Recurrent Prostate Cancer and Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: I was really just looking for a general discussion of AS (or AWW) after surgery. I have another thread about my specific situation. I have seen 2 local urologists and 2 local radiologists and I have an appointment at the Mayo Clinic in about a month. They have me scheduled for a Choline PET scan followed by a T3 MRI. Hopefully, Ill have a much better idea of whats going on after the tests and a discussion with Dr Choo. I understand AS after diagnosis. Im not sure if I had it to do over again, whether I would go that route or not. Maybe. Theres no use wondering since that ship has sailed. I just find it interesting that theres no discussion of AS after surgery. And that ship has not yet sailed for me. With a confirmed Gleason 6 and 99+% of the cancer surgically removed, wouldnt AS (or AWW) be worth considering based on your age at recurrence, time (years) it took to recur, doubling rate of the PSA, etc? And consider that it is almost impossible for a Gleason 6 to metastasize. It is also supposed to be virtually impossible for a Gleason 6 cell to survive outside of the prostate. Maybe ASAdvocate might have some thoughts on this subject. Chuck  I like your possibility of benign prostate tissue. It could be. But since I had a positive margin, I doubt it. But Ill keep that in the back of my mind as something to hope for.

Posts.Title: Recurrent Prostate Cancer and Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: I have a general question about recurrent prostate cancer and Active Surveillance. Thats AS with a capital A and a capital S. Not just watchful waiting. Ive read a lot, a whole lot, about AS, but I cant seem to find anything about AS after surgery. It seems on this forum that once it is determined that the cancer is back, then its time to have radiation done ASAP. And it seems that the earlier (.03 vs .20) you have radiation the better. No one seems to talk about AS at this point. Are there even established AS programs at places like Johns Hopkins for recurrent prostate cancer? Ive seen the chart that talks about how long it takes for the PSA to start going up after surgery, and how long it takes for the PSA to double. Are these factors in recurrent prostate cancer AS? As a wise man once said, according to medical research, it is almost impossible for a Gleason 6 to metastasize. It is also supposed to be virtually impossible for a Gleason 6 cell to survive outside of the prostate. So, if there is a recurrence, it is seemingly a 1 in a million situation. As for the 3+3 progressing to a higher Gleason grade, that does not happen. However a cancer cell forms, it remains at that same Gleason grade. If Gleason 6 is confirmed after surgery, is AS a possibility with recurrent prostate cancer?

Posts.Title: Recurrent Prostate Cancer and Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: This is a general question. I know that certain things can impact your PSA score. Since I have had my prostate removed, Im really asking about PSA after surgical prostate removal. But I dont want to get into the details of my PSA results. Id rather discuss this in general terms. Using a different lab can impact your PSA. By how much? 10%? 20%? If you had a PSA of .50 using one lab, and you had your next test done at a different lab, and lets assume there wasnt any REAL/ACTUAL change, would you expect the number to be between .45 and .55? Between .40 and .60? I know these are small numbers, but small numbers are important when you have had your prostate removed and youre wondering if you still have cancer. Exercising, having sex, and other activities right before the sample is taken can impact your PSA. Again, Im curious by how much? But Ive also heard that those activities will only affect your PSA if you still have a prostate. True or false?

Posts.Content: Michael F Thanks for the reply. As I said in my first post in this thread, I didnt want to get into the details of my PSA results. Id rather discuss this subject in general terms. That was because of the other thread you mentioned, where Ive gotten a lot of great replies about my specific situation. My URO surgeon was not the one who said he uses the PSA number 1.0 to start radiation. That was the first radiation oncologist I went to. But he also said I need to go ahead and get it scheduled. My URO surgeon said for me not to worry and that its not time to take any action. And not surprisingly, that was the last time I will ever see him. You said Your PSA is in a range where some of the newer PET Scan technologies should be able to pinpoint the location(s). Consider going to one of the "PC Meccas" such as MD Anderson for a consultation and formulation of a solid game plan. In my other thread, where Im discussing my specific situation (not a general discussion about PSA), I posted a few days ago that Im currently scheduled at the Mayo Clinic to have a Choline PET scan followed by a 3T MRI. And yes, I know that with a Gleason 6, and no PSA increase for several years, and not doubling every 10 months, I am truly blessed compared to a LOT of others on this forum. I plan to do my research, put a plan together, carry out the plan, and KILL this cancer this time.

Maybe ASAdvocate might have some thoughts on this subject. Chuck  I like your possibility of benign prostate tissue. It could be. But since I had a positive margin, I doubt it. But Ill keep that in the back of my mind as something to hope for.

Posts.Title: Recurrent Prostate Cancer and Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: Southsider - Thank you for the input. I have another thread about my specific situation (see It's Back). I was just hoping to generate some general discussion about post surgery rise in PSA. I realize that for a lot of people, it's simple. They had RP. Their first post surgery PSA is 1+ and it's doubling quickly. No doubt, it's time to take action. Then there are other folks who had little or no rise in PSA for a long time. And now it's going up very slowly. Sometimes it IS sort of tricky to decide when (or if) to start salvage radiation. What would the trigger be?

Posts.Title: Recurrent Prostate Cancer and Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: Let me start by saying that I wish I had found this site 11 years ago, instead of last month. Im 69 years old. At about age 55, each time I would have my annual physical done, my family doctor (who I no longer use) would do the DRE and say something like that doesnt feel right, but since your PSA is only about 1, youre OK. At age 58, I went to a urologist because I thought I had an enlarged prostate. He did the DRE and said you need a biopsy now. So at age 58, with a PSA of 1.75, I was diagnosed with prostate cancer (see signature for biopsy results). I thought Oh no, my life is over. I researched my options; active surveillance, radiation, or surgery. After much soul searching and discussions with my wife, I decided to have surgery. I chose a local urologist who had not done very many DaVinci procedures, but I liked his bedside manner. I had the surgery right after Christmas 2006 (see signature for surgery results). I had the usual incontinence issues, but they cleared up after a while. I had the usual erectile problems, but they havent cleared up. Bummer. Since I had positive margins, my urologist discussed the pros and cons of having radiation following my surgery. I decided to wait and hope the cancer would not come back. Six months after surgery, my PSA was zero. Yea! Six months later, it was .01 and I was worried. I know, a .01 doesnt mean anything. Six months later, and it hadnt changed. OK. Six months later, and it was zero again. Yea. Life is good. Six months later and it was still zero. OK, I was seeing a pattern and I liked it. Six months later and it was back to .01 but I was not worried. A year later, 2011 and 4 years after my surgery, it was .02. Hmmm. Still not significant. One year later (2012) it was at .04 and I did NOT like where this was probably heading. As you can see from the PSA numbers in my signature below, my cancer is back. My number is at the magic .2 thats used to define the recurrence of prostate cancer. The good news is that my Gleason was 6 (3+3). And that my PSA didnt really start going up until about 4-5 years after surgery. And that my PSA is not doubling every year (yet). So now what? My urologist, the same one who did the surgery, told me not to worry and its not time yet to take action. I asked him for the name of the radiation oncologist he would recommend (when the time was right) and I went to see him. He explained IMRT and the associated hormone therapy. He said he uses the PSA number 1.0 (after surgery) as the latest time to start the radiation treatments. He said its not urgent, but I need to go ahead and get it scheduled. My brother also has/had prostate cancer and also went with the DaVinci surgery. He had his surgery done at MD Anderson about 3 years ago. So far, so good. I went to see the local urologist he uses for check-ups each year. I wanted another opinion from another urologist. He reminded me that my Gleason was 6 (3+3), and my PSA didnt really start going up until about 4-5 years after surgery, and my PSA is not doubling every year (yet). He recommended active surveillance. He said in my situation, he would use the PSA number 10.0 (after surgery) as the latest time to start the radiation treatments, unless my numbers start doubling in a year or less. And he reminded me that a Gleason 6 (3+3) almost never metastasizes. I asked that urologist which radiation oncologist he would recommend, and made an appointment with him. As it turns out, he worked at ProCure, the proton therapy place here in Oklahoma City. This is good because I wanted to meet with someone to discuss proton therapy. He said even though he works at ProCure, he recommends IMRT for salvage radiation therapy. Like the previous radiation oncologist, he said he uses the PSA number 1.0 (after surgery) as the latest time to start the radiation treatments. He said its not urgent, but I need to go ahead and get it scheduled. He does not recommend hormone therapy before or during radiation treatments. OK, Ive seen two urologists and two radiation oncologists. Both urologists said wait. Both radiation oncologists said get it done. Im sorry this post is so long. I wanted to give you guys enough information so that you can provide me some good advice. I have several questions. Lets start with should I wait or should I get it done?

Posts.Title: It's Back

Posts.Content: Thanks to all of you for your quick replies. Michael F - "you can excise your URO MDs from your opinion pool." I agree. I like both URO MDs, but active surveillance (AS) is not for me. So their job is done. Jim215 - "It would be a damn shame to guess wrong now." I've seen it said on this forum, that there is no wrong decision. I'm not sure I agree. I believe AS would be the wrong guess for me. MichiganMan16 - "I would be acting....yesterday." As both radiation oncologists said, its not urgent, but I need to go ahead and get it scheduled. I agree. It's time to get er done. But I need a plan. I know the experience of a surgeon is critical. But, how important is to choose the right radiation oncologist? Would I have better results if I go to an expert location? Like MD Anderson, John Hopkins, Mayo Clinic, etc? There would be some inconvenience having to live for two months in another city during the SRT. But if it will produce better results, Ill do it. However, if all SRT is about the same, and the results will be the same if I have it done in a facility two miles from my home, then thats a better choice for me. Those of you who have had SRT, or are wise in this area, please let me know what you think. Thanks in advance.

Posts.Content: Let me start by saying that I wish I had found this site 11 years ago, instead of last month. Im 69 years old. At about age 55, each time I would have my annual physical done, my family doctor (who I no longer use) would do the DRE and say something like that doesnt feel right, but since your PSA is only about 1, youre OK. At age 58, I went to a urologist because I thought I had an enlarged prostate. He did the DRE and said you need a biopsy now. So at age 58, with a PSA of 1.75, I was diagnosed with prostate cancer (see signature for biopsy results). I thought Oh no, my life is over. I researched my options; active surveillance, radiation, or surgery. After much soul searching and discussions with my wife, I decided to have surgery. I chose a local urologist who had not done very many DaVinci procedures, but I liked his bedside manner. I had the surgery right after Christmas 2006 (see signature for surgery results). I had the usual incontinence issues, but they cleared up after a while. I had the usual erectile problems, but they havent cleared up. Bummer. Since I had positive margins, my urologist discussed the pros and cons of having radiation following my surgery. I decided to wait and hope the cancer would not come back. Six months after surgery, my PSA was zero. Yea! Six months later, it was .01 and I was worried. I know, a .01 doesnt mean anything. Six months later, and it hadnt changed. OK. Six months later, and it was zero again. Yea. Life is good. Six months later and it was still zero. OK, I was seeing a pattern and I liked it. Six months later and it was back to .01 but I was not worried. A year later, 2011 and 4 years after my surgery, it was .02. Hmmm. Still not significant. One year later (2012) it was at .04 and I did NOT like where this was probably heading. As you can see from the PSA numbers in my signature below, my cancer is back. My number is at the magic .2 thats used to define the recurrence of prostate cancer. The good news is that my Gleason was 6 (3+3). And that my PSA didnt really start going up until about 4-5 years after surgery. And that my PSA is not doubling every year (yet). So now what? My urologist, the same one who did the surgery, told me not to worry and its not time yet to take action. I asked him for the name of the radiation oncologist he would recommend (when the time was right) and I went to see him. He explained IMRT and the associated hormone therapy. He said he uses the PSA number 1.0 (after surgery) as the latest time to start the radiation treatments. He said its not urgent, but I need to go ahead and get it scheduled. My brother also has/had prostate cancer and also went with the DaVinci surgery. He had his surgery done at MD Anderson about 3 years ago. So far, so good. I went to see the local urologist he uses for check-ups each year. I wanted another opinion from another urologist. He reminded me that my Gleason was 6 (3+3), and my PSA didnt really start going up until about 4-5 years after surgery, and my PSA is not doubling every year (yet). He recommended active surveillance. He said in my situation, he would use the PSA number 10.0 (after surgery) as the latest time to start the radiation treatments, unless my numbers start doubling in a year or less. And he reminded me that a Gleason 6 (3+3) almost never metastasizes. I asked that urologist which radiation oncologist he would recommend, and made an appointment with him. As it turns out, he worked at ProCure, the proton therapy place here in Oklahoma City. This is good because I wanted to meet with someone to discuss proton therapy. He said even though he works at ProCure, he recommends IMRT for salvage radiation therapy. Like the previous radiation oncologist, he said he uses the PSA number 1.0 (after surgery) as the latest time to start the radiation treatments. He said its not urgent, but I need to go ahead and get it scheduled. He does not recommend hormone therapy before or during radiation treatments. OK, Ive seen two urologists and two radiation oncologists. Both urologists said wait. Both radiation oncologists said get it done. Im sorry this post is so long. I wanted to give you guys enough information so that you can provide me some good advice. I have several questions. Lets start with should I wait or should I get it done?

Posts.Title: From Hopkins - Margins - Don't Panic if not Negative

Posts.Content: Thanks to all of you for your quick replies. Michael F - "you can excise your URO MDs from your opinion pool." I agree. I like both URO MDs, but active surveillance (AS) is not for me. So their job is done. Jim215 - "It would be a damn shame to guess wrong now." I've seen it said on this forum, that there is no wrong decision. I'm not sure I agree. I believe AS would be the wrong guess for me. MichiganMan16 - "I would be acting....yesterday." As both radiation oncologists said, its not urgent, but I need to go ahead and get it scheduled. I agree. It's time to get er done. But I need a plan. I know the experience of a surgeon is critical. But, how important is to choose the right radiation oncologist? Would I have better results if I go to an expert location? Like MD Anderson, John Hopkins, Mayo Clinic, etc? There would be some inconvenience having to live for two months in another city during the SRT. But if it will produce better results, Ill do it. However, if all SRT is about the same, and the results will be the same if I have it done in a facility two miles from my home, then thats a better choice for me. Those of you who have had SRT, or are wise in this area, please let me know what you think. Thanks in advance.

Posts.Content: Do Gleason patterns transition from one pattern to a higher pattern? Or once a 3, always a 3? Can a pattern 3 left untreated long enough, become a pattern 4? Or is a pattern 4 a completely different "animal" than a pattern 3? When a person is diagnosed with a pattern 4, for example, could it have been a pattern 3 before it was a pattern 4? Even briefly? Or did it develop originally as a pattern 4, and will forever be a pattern 4? I have the same questions pertaining to patterns 4 and 5. I realize that we're not doctors, but what do our forum brothers think?
